result.execSummary:
The defendant Joseph T Krech was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Habitual Criminality], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Defendant, Joseph T Krech with Attorney John Charles Bachman appeared.  Prosecuting attorney Renee M Taber.  Kim Silvius - Clerk
(11:05)    MULTIPLE CASES HEARD.
State - would like to address any issue the deft has with his attorney before trial
Bachman - was present at handwriting sample - requests continuance, deft has several witnesses and hasn't been able to track them down, there are other police reports that haven't been provided, deft had trial evidence in his truck that was stolen last night - not sure he can get copies of everything again
State - objects to continuance
State argues motion to allow specific evidence from N.R.
Bachman - argues
State - addresses video exhibits

COURT:  denies motion for continuance - deft to do what he can to get evidence and we can take up at trial it's relevance
on Motion filed by State - handwriting exemplar - not going to be an expert witness and deft hasn't been harmed  - motion for ineffective counsel is denied
State motion to allow specific evidence N.R. - mostly likely would allow the computer that contained the evidence for underlying charges but may be certain parts restricted
State motion in limine - number of convictions parties to come to agreement - parties agree on 5 convictions
will use technology we have to post video exhibits to jurors

JT goes on 4th & 5th

bonds continue

in 15CF34 have to do amended JOC showing repeater showing 1B rather then 1A
